title: Contemplating chapter 7. $100k unsecured debt but own cars, tax refund, pending civil lawsuit?
question: I have about $100k in CC debt. Lost my job last month, started a new one but the missed payment has pushed the minimums way out of my budget. I have been sued by one creditor and need to sign a stipulated judgment soon. I own a couple of cars, one free and clear one purchased less than 1 year ago and financed. I'm also expecting a tax refund and am currently plaintiff in a civil suit. Is chapter 7 a viable option? Will I lose my cars? Will I lose any potential settlement and tax refund? Will I be able to discharge the debt I've been sued for already?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Unsecured debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: Bankruptcy sounds very promising for someone in your financial situation. Before you make any moves, consult with 2-3 Avvo BK lawyers offering a free consultation by phone or in person. Pick one who has excellent reviews left by current or former clients who have actually consulted with or hired the attorney. A good BK attorney will promptly return phone messages, discuss your options without using a lot of "legalese", completely answer/explain what the process is, how long it takes, what are the costs, etc.

You may file a chapter 7 bankruptcy to discharge all of your dischargeable debts. When you file all of your property becomes part of the bankruptcy estate. To keep your property you must use exemptions. This is where an attorney's knowledge comes in handy. I suggest you consult with a knowledge bankruptcy attorney in your area, now, before you sign the stipulated judgment.

When you file bankruptcy all your assets and debts become part of a bankruptcy “estate” which is controlled by the US Trustee, an arm of the Dept of Justice.

You will only be able to keep assets which are exempt.

Do not sign any stipulated judgment until you have talked to a bankruptcy attorney, which you should do soon.
I suggest you contact a bankruptcy attorney and discuss your specific situation and concerns. Most attorneys offer a free consultation.

Chapter 7 may be a viable option for you but whether it is the best option and when you should be filing are questions that should be answered by an experienced bankruptcy attorney to insure that you do not lose your tax refund and to address issued with the lawsuit in which you are a plaintiff. A debt that you have already been sued for, even one that has gone to judgment, stipulated or otherwise, is generally one that can be discharged in a bankruptcy case.
